contentSections.title: The Invisible Army
contentSections.content: Prokaryotic cells like bacteria have no nucleus, no mitochondria, and no membrane-bound organelles. Yet they can reproduce rapidly‚Äîone E. coli cell can become 17 million cells in just 12 hours.

contentSections.title: Key Prokaryotic Structures
contentSections.content: Nucleoid region (DNA with no membrane), 70S ribosomes (smaller than eukaryotic 80S), peptidoglycan cell wall, flagella for movement, and plasmids for antibiotic resistance.

contentSections.title: Why Antibiotics Work
contentSections.content: Antibiotics exploit structural differences: bacterial 70S ribosomes differ from human 80S ribosomes, allowing selective toxicity. Penicillin targets the unique peptidoglycan cell wall.

contentHTML:
ü¶† The Invisible Army

Imagine a single Escherichia coli bacterium settling on a nutrient-rich surface. Within 12 hours, that one cell can become 17 million cells‚Äîenough to form a visible colony the size of a coin.

Yet this remarkable organism has:

  • ‚ùå No nucleus‚Äîjust a nucleoid region
  • ‚ùå No mitochondria‚Äîenergy production happens at the cell membrane
  • ‚ùå No membrane-bound organelles‚Äîjust cytoplasm with 70S ribosomes
Critical Question: How does such a 'simple' cell survive, reproduce, and outcompete complex organisms? And why can penicillin kill bacteria but not harm your cells?

üî¨ Basic Prokaryotic Structure

Prokaryotic Cell

üìã Key Prokaryotic Structures

Structure Description Function
Nucleoid Region containing circular DNA; no surrounding membrane Stores genetic information; controls cell activities
70S Ribosomes Smaller than eukaryotic ribosomes (50S + 30S subunits) Site of protein synthesis
Cell Wall Made of peptidoglycan (bacteria) or pseudopeptidoglycan (archaea) Provides structure and protection; maintains cell shape
Plasmids Small circular DNA separate from main chromosome Often carry antibiotic resistance genes
Flagella Tail-like appendages (lack 9+2 microtubule arrangement) Movement; chemotaxis

‚öñÔ∏è Prokaryotic vs Eukaryotic Cells

Feature Prokaryotic Eukaryotic
Nucleus Nucleoid region (no membrane) True nucleus (double membrane)
DNA Shape Circular Linear (in nucleus)
Ribosomes 70S (smaller) 80S (larger)
Organelles None membrane-bound Mitochondria, ER, Golgi, etc.
Cell Wall Peptidoglycan (bacteria) Cellulose (plants) or chitin (fungi) or none
Size 1‚Äì10 ¬µm 10‚Äì100 ¬µm
Examples Bacteria, Archaea Animals, Plants, Fungi, Protists
üí° Memory Tip: Think 'pro' = 'no' (prokaryotes have NO membrane-bound nucleus). 'Eu' = 'true' (eukaryotes have a TRUE nucleus).

üíä Case Study: Antibiotics and Selective Toxicity

When you take antibiotics for a bacterial infection, how do they kill bacteria without harming your cells? The answer lies in selective toxicity‚Äîtargeting structures unique to bacteria.

Selective Toxicity Formula:
Target Structure = Bacterial Only (NOT in Human Cells)
Examples: 70S ribosomes, peptidoglycan cell wall

Antibiotic Mechanisms:

  • Tetracycline: Binds to 30S ribosomal subunit ‚Üí blocks protein synthesis
  • Penicillin: Inhibits peptidoglycan synthesis ‚Üí weakens cell wall ‚Üí lysis
  • Streptomycin: Binds to 16S rRNA ‚Üí misreading of mRNA

üìù Worked Example: Why Antibiotics Work

Question: Explain why tetracycline can kill bacteria without harming human cells.

Step 1: Identify the target structure
Tetracycline targets bacterial ribosomes (70S), which are smaller than human ribosomes (80S).
Step 2: Explain the structural difference
70S ribosomes consist of 50S and 30S subunits with distinct shapes and rRNA sequences compared to the 60S and 40S subunits of 80S ribosomes.
Step 3: Describe the mechanism
Tetracycline binds to the 30S subunit of 70S ribosomes, blocking the A-site and preventing tRNA attachment, thus stopping protein synthesis.
Step 4: Explain selectivity
The 80S ribosomes in human cells have a different structure that does not bind tetracycline, so protein synthesis in human cells continues normally. This is selective toxicity.

‚ö†Ô∏è Common Misconceptions

Misconception: 'Prokaryotes have a nucleus'

Correction: Students confuse 'nucleoid' with 'nucleus' due to similar names. Nucleoid = NO membrane; Nucleus = HAS membrane.

Analogy: Nucleoid is like a pile of string in a room; nucleus is that string inside a sealed bag.

Misconception: 'All bacteria are harmful'

Correction: Only a small percentage of bacteria cause disease. Gut bacteria (microbiome) aid digestion, produce vitamins, and protect against pathogens.

Misconception: 'Prokaryotes are primitive/simple'

Correction: Simple structure does not mean simple function. Bacteria display incredible metabolic diversity: nitrogen fixation, extreme environment survival, complex communication (quorum sensing).

üî¨ Check Your Understanding

Question: Why can't we see ribosomes under a light microscope?

Answer: 70S ribosomes are approximately 20‚Äì30 nm in size, well below the ~200 nm resolution limit of light microscopes. Electron microscopes are required to visualise them.

activities.title: Match Structures to Functions
activities.description: Match each prokaryotic structure with its correct function. Understanding structure-function relationships is key to HSC success!

multipleChoice.question: Which structure is found in prokaryotic cells but absent from eukaryotic cells?
multipleChoice.rationale: Both cell types have ribosomes and DNA. Only eukaryotes have membrane-bound nucleus. Peptidoglycan cell wall is specific to bacteria (prokaryotes).

multipleChoice.question: The main difference between the nucleoid of a bacterium and the nucleus of an animal cell is that the nucleoid:
options: Is not surrounded by a membrane
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Is not surrounded by a membrane
multipleChoice.rationale: Students often think 'nucleoid' means 'small nucleus' with membrane. The key difference is nucleoid has NO membrane, while nucleus HAS a double membrane.

multipleChoice.question: Antibiotics such as tetracycline are effective against bacteria because they:
multipleChoice.rationale: Antibiotics exploit the difference between 70S (bacterial) and 80S (human) ribosomes. Penicillin destroys cell walls; tetracycline targets ribosomes.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells with reference to the presence of a nucleus and the structure of ribosomes. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Prokaryotes have nucleoid region (no membrane) vs eukaryotes have membrane-bound nucleus
1 mark: Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes vs eukaryotes have 80S ribosomes
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating prokaryotes have 'no DNA' or confusing 70S/80S sizes. Remember: 70S are SMALLER (found in prokaryotes).

shortAnswer.question: Explain why bacterial cells can be killed by antibiotics that target their ribosomes, while human cells are not affected. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Bacterial ribosomes are 70S (small) while human ribosomes are 80S (different structure)
1 mark: Antibiotics can bind to/block 70S ribosomes but not 80S ribosomes (selective toxicity)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'bacteria are weaker' rather than explaining structural difference. Focus on the 70S vs 80S distinction.

activities.title: Label the Prokaryotic Cell - Answer Key

answers.label: Nucleoid
answers.description: The region containing the circular bacterial chromosome. Key point: NO membrane surrounds it (unlike a true nucleus).

answers.label: Cell wall
answers.description: Rigid layer made of peptidoglycan that provides structural support and protection. Found external to the plasma membrane.

answers.label: Ribosome
answers.description: 70S ribosomes (smaller than eukaryotic 80S) scattered throughout the cytoplasm. Site of protein synthesis.

answers.label: Flagellum
answers.description: Long, whip-like appendage used for locomotion. Lacks the 9+2 microtubule arrangement of eukaryotic flagella.

answers.label: Plasmid
answers.description: Small, circular, extrachromosomal DNA molecule. Often carries antibiotic resistance genes and can be transferred between bacteria.

answers.label: Capsule
answers.description: Gel-like layer outside the cell wall. Provides protection and helps bacteria adhere to surfaces.

activities.keyPoint: The most critical distinction is the nucleoid vs nucleus‚Äîprokaryotes have no membrane-bound nucleus!

activities.title: Match Structures to Functions - Answer Key

answers.label: Nucleoid ‚Üí Contains genetic information (circular DNA)
answers.description: The nucleoid is not a true organelle but a concentrated region of DNA that controls cellular activities.

answers.label: 70S ribosome ‚Üí Site of protein synthesis
answers.description: Composed of 50S and 30S subunits. The 'S' unit refers to Svedberg units (sedimentation rate).

answers.label: Peptidoglycan wall ‚Üí Provides protection and structure
answers.description: Unique to bacteria (archaea have different cell wall compositions). Target of penicillin antibiotics.

answers.label: Plasmid ‚Üí Carries antibiotic resistance genes
answers.description: Can replicate independently and be transferred between bacteria via conjugation.

answers.label: Flagella ‚Üí Enables cell movement
answers.description: Rotates like a propeller (different from the whipping motion of eukaryotic flagella).

activities.keyPoint: Understanding structure-function relationships is essential for HSC questions on cell biology.

assessment.question: Which structure is found in prokaryotic cells but absent from eukaryotic cells?
assessment.explanation: Both cell types have ribosomes and DNA. Eukaryotes have membrane-bound nuclei (not prokaryotes). Peptidoglycan cell walls are unique to bacteria (a type of prokaryote). Plant cells have cellulose walls; fungi have chitin walls‚Äîbut these are eukaryotes with different wall compositions.

assessment.question: The main difference between the nucleoid of a bacterium and the nucleus of an animal cell is that the nucleoid:
assessment.correctAnswer: B - Is not surrounded by a membrane
assessment.explanation: The name 'nucleoid' sounds like 'nucleus' but they differ fundamentally. The nucleoid is simply a region where DNA is concentrated‚Äîthere is no membrane envelope. The eukaryotic nucleus is surrounded by a double membrane (nuclear envelope) with pores. The nucleoid contains circular DNA; the nucleus contains linear DNA.

assessment.question: Antibiotics such as tetracycline are effective against bacteria because they:
assessment.explanation: Selective toxicity is the principle here. Bacterial ribosomes are 70S (50S + 30S subunits) while human ribosomes are 80S (60S + 40S subunits). Tetracycline binds to the 30S subunit and blocks protein synthesis in bacteria. Human ribosomes are unaffected because their different structure prevents antibiotic binding.

assessment.question: Distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells with reference to the presence of a nucleus and the structure of ribosomes. (2 marks)
assessment.correctAnswer: Prokaryotic cells have a nucleoid region (not surrounded by a membrane) whereas eukaryotic cells have a membrane-bound nucleus (1 mark). Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes which are smaller than the 80S ribosomes found in eukaryotes (1 mark).
assessment.explanation: Full marks require clear distinction on both criteria. Note that 'nucleoid' must be described as lacking a membrane. For ribosomes, mentioning the Svedberg values (70S vs 80S) or simply stating prokaryotic ribosomes are smaller earns the mark.

assessment.question: Explain why bacterial cells can be killed by antibiotics that target their ribosomes, while human cells are not affected. (2 marks)
assessment.correctAnswer: Bacterial cells have 70S ribosomes which have a different structure from the 80S ribosomes in human cells (1 mark). Antibiotics like tetracycline can bind to the 70S ribosomes and block protein synthesis in bacteria, but they cannot bind to the larger 80S ribosomes in human cells, so protein synthesis in human cells is not affected. This is called selective toxicity (1 mark).
assessment.explanation: The key concept is selective toxicity‚Äîexploiting structural differences. The answer must mention 70S vs 80S ribosomes and explain that the antibiotic can bind to bacterial but not human ribosomes. The term 'selective toxicity' is excellent but not essential if the concept is clearly explained.
